entry.title: How this laid-back Southern city became a culinary hot spot
entry.summary: Greenville, South Carolina, is home to Michelin's North America headquarters. Local chefs say that encourages and inspires them to aim for culinary excellence in their kitchens. Greenvilleâ€”home to Michelinâ€™s North America headquarters and the setting for the next season of Top Chefâ€”has transformed from a Southern-centered food city into a culinary melting pot. In the middle of the morning on a hot Sunday in September, a handful of people are feverishly chopping, dicing, and slicing while a large camera crew and passersby observe their progress. These active culinary wizards are competitors on the reality show â€œTop Chef,â€ now in its 23rd season. Greenville, South Carolina, a Southern city in a part of South Carolina called the Upstate, is the setting for this season's shâ€¦

entry.title: What itâ€™s like to raft the Urubamba in Peruâ€™s Sacred Valley
entry.summary:
The Urubamba River winds through Peruâ€™s Sacred Valley in countless bends and turns. Rafting the Urubamba River reveals a side of the Sacred Valley few hikers ever see, with trails etched into the hillsides, birds rising from the reeds and ancient, glacier-crowned peaks standing sentinel above it all.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Cutting through Peruâ€™s Sacred Valley like a lifeline, the Urubamba River is fed by ancient glaciers and flanked by Inca ruins, terraced farmland and eucalyptus-covered hillsides. Itâ€™s along this historic waterway that I find myself donning a wetsuit and helmet on a pebbled riverbank near Pachar, ready to experience the Sacred Valley from an entirely new perspective â€” by raft.
After a safety briefing from our câ€¦

entry.title: Where to hike in Europe in winter
entry.summary:
Donâ€™t chuck your hiking boots in a cupboard and forget about them just because itâ€™s winter â€” there are plenty of great walks to take on this time of year. Winter neednâ€™t be your off-season. There are magnificent hikes to be enjoyed on many of the continentâ€™s coastlines and islands, as well as along its sun-kissed southern edge, which is often too hot for serious summer walks. Here are seven seasonal trails to take on.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Europe is home to scores of excellent hiking destinations that can be enjoyed in any season. In fact, many of the best are simply too hot and/or crowded to be hiked comfortably in the summer months and really come into their own when itâ€™s cooler. In others, youâ€™ll find their edge-of-civilisation aâ€¦

entry.title: The ancient origins of the Chinese zodiac
entry.summary:
An antique Chinese copper coin carving with the twelve Chinese zodiac signs. The ancient system links 12 animal signs to birth years and shapes Chinese culture by influencing personality, compatibility, career, and fortune-telling. Long before Western astrology, the Chinese zodiac helped organize years, beliefs, and social life. Hereâ€™s how the system of 12 animals evolved over the centuries.
Are you a rat, ox, tiger, rabbit, dragon, snake, horse, goat, monkey, rooster, dog, or pig?Â
That question is central to the Chinese zodiac, an ancient astrological system still relevant in Chinese cultureâ€”and around the worldâ€”today. Rife with myth and legend, the system assigns different years and animals to people born in each year, then projects personality traits based on those animalâ€¦

entry.title: Flying in 2026? Hereâ€™s how to find the cheapest flights
entry.summary:
Flight alerts help travelers track fluctuating prices, so you know when your ideal flight drops in cost. From myth-busting outdated tips to the best search tools and AI, travel experts weigh in on how to find affordable airfare.
Booking affordable airfare can be a turbulent process. Prices rise and fall day by day, or in some cases, hour by hour. In the past, frequent fliers swore by loose strategies to find dealsâ€”book on a Tuesday! No, on a Wednesday! Never on a weekend! But experts caution that many suggestions donâ€™t amount to more than myth.
While finding cheap airfare might feel futile, itâ€™s not impossible. Hereâ€™s what experts say you need to know.
If youâ€™re looking for a cross-country flight this summer, youâ€™ll notice that the prices tend to go up and down. One dayâ€¦

entry.title: You might be stretching the wrong way, scientists say
entry.summary:
Some fitness experts recommend stretching before a workout, while others argue it's more important to stretch afterwards. Now, there is finally consensus on the best ways to stretch. A new wave of research is showing what the old gym myths about stretching got wrongâ€”and what you really need to do to reap its benefits.
You probably know itâ€™s important to incorporate stretching into your fitness routine, but you may be confusedÂ about the best approach. After all, even fitness experts havenâ€™t always seen eye-to-eye on the subject. Some experts recommend stretching before a workout, others say itâ€™s more effective to stretch after. Complicating matters, there are so many different ways to stretchâ€”including static stretching, dynamic stretching, and passive or assisted stretching.
â€œâ€¦

entry.title: How a polar researcher deals with hypothermia in the field
entry.summary:
Photographer Esther Horvath stands on the ice near the German research icebreaker ship Polarstern. The German research icebreaker Polarstern was the setting for the MOSAiC expeditionâ€”the largest Arctic research project in history looking at the Arctic Ocean as the epicenter of global warming. The year-long expedition began in September of 2019 and concluded on October 12, 2020. In subzero winds, hypothermia announces itself in small, easy-to-miss ways. Hereâ€™s what one Nat Geo Explorer does to combat it in some of the coldest places on Earth.
Blink, and your eyelashes freeze together. Exhale, and your breath turns to ice crystals. Expose any part of your skin, and it's instantly threatened byÂ frostbite.
National Geographic ExplorerÂ Esther HorvathÂ has stood â€¦

entry.title: How breast cancer research is helping prostate cancer patients
entry.summary:
A recent study has validated the first genetic test for prostate cancer that tells doctors exactly which patients need hormone therapy and which can safely skip it. Decades ago, doctors created a test to determine which breast cancer patients should receive hormone therapy. Now, researchers are using the same tactics to advance prostate cancer treatment.
For decades, oncologists treating prostate cancer patients were operating in the dark. They knew that adding hormone therapy to radiation treatment could kill cancer cells more effectively than radiation alone. But for some patients, this addition didn't help them live longer or improve their outcomesâ€”and it also subjected them to hormone therapy's menopause-like side effects.Â
â€œEach patient has their own unique cancer, so howâ€¦

entry.title: Inside the quest to build the ultimate nonalcoholic beer
entry.summary:
Kevin Verstrepenâ€™s lab at the University of Leuven in Belgium is ground zero for a new approach to brewing nonalcoholic beer that could reinvigorate a flagging industry. Scientists in Belgiumâ€”that celebrated bastion of ancient beer cultureâ€”are harnessing genetic breakthroughs and machine learning to reimagine how great booze gets built. Hereâ€™s how their revelations in the lab could transform the global beer industry.
The secretive beer labÂ inside the headquarters of the worldâ€™s biggest brewing company doesnâ€™t often allow visitors. But today AB InBev has something it would like to show off. So David De Schutter, the head of AB InBevâ€™s Global Innovation and Technology Centerâ€”the official name of the beer labâ€”is showing me around the squat black building on the outskirts of Leuveâ€¦

entry.title: 7 reasons why Aomori should be on your Japan travel itinerary
entry.summary:
One of Japanâ€™s few remaining â€˜originalâ€™ castles, Hirosaki Castle will return to its original location in 2026 after having been moved for restoration. While most travellers head south of Tokyo, those who venture up to the far north of Honshu island will be rewarded with Japanâ€™s trademark scenic trains, samurai castles and local crafts â€” but fewer crowds.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In Japanâ€™s under-explored Tohoku region, the vast prefecture of Aomori unfolds as a landscape of bucolic plains and peaks. For adventurous travellers, it offers a quiet alternative to the busy southern touring circuit. One of Japanâ€™s most famous festivals â€” Nebuta Matsuri â€” takes place here in August, but Aomori is also home to sake breweries, cherry blossom hoâ€¦

entry.title: Why your brain sometimes works against your goals
entry.summary:
Behaviors like procrastination and avoidance may feel like poor self-control, but research suggests theyâ€™re often linked to how the brain processes stress and perceived threat. Research shows that delaying important tasks is often driven by how the brain processes stress and threatâ€”not by poor time management or lack of discipline.
The deadline has been on your calendar for weeks. But the night before, the work still isnâ€™t done. You may have underestimated how long it would take, overthought how to get it right, or worried about how it would be received.
If this scenario sounds familiar, you may be experiencing a form of self-sabotage, a pattern â€œthat we do to ourselves, often unconsciously, that kind of derails our lives or our plans or our goals,â€ says Charlie Heriot-Maitlanâ€¦

entry.title: 50 of our favorite U.S. state parks
entry.summary:
As an alternative to a U.S. national park, travelers can visit less-crowded state parks, such as Red Rock State Park in Sedona, Arizona. From Niagara Falls to the Redwood Forests, state parks preserve many of the nationâ€™s iconic landscapes and historic treasures. With more than 10,000 to choose from, hereâ€™s a look at one from each state.
For some U.S. residents, it can take a day or two to reach the nearest national park. And when you finally arriveâ€”especially during the busy summer months and shoulder seasonsâ€”the parks are often too crowded to truly enjoy. But state parks are an easy alternative.
According to theÂ National Association of State Park Directors, there are between 6,000 to nearly 9,800 designated state parks and areas in the U.S., which means thereâ€™s probably one â€¦

entry.title: How to set up a bird feeder to attract your favorite species
Inside spogomi, the growing competitive sport of picking up trash
Cruise travel is changingâ€”here are the biggest trends for 2026
entry.summary:
Gen Z travellers are more eager than ever to embark on their own cruising holidays. We explore the trends â€” from nautical nostalgia to silent sailings â€” making waves in the coming year and beyond.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With more diverse itineraries and ships to sail on than ever before, nowâ€™s most definitely the time to book an adventure on the ocean or river. Still think cruising is strictly retiree territory? Pack away that perception â€” according to a 2025 CLIA report, 76% of gen Z who have previously been on a cruise plan to set sail again in the future.Â
The sheer variety on offer means you can cruise a coastline in quiet contemplation or take a deep dive into your favourite sport or cuisine. From immersive, money-canâ€™t-buyâ€¦

entry.title: Eighty years at the heart of global development
entry.summary: From humanitarian crises and youth unemployment to climate resilience and development financing, many of todayâ€™s global challenges pass through a single United Nations body that is quietly turning 80 this year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN warns of rising internet shutdowns as digital blackouts spread worldwide
entry.summary: A rising trend towards government-enforced internet shutdowns â€“ with at least 300 incidents in more than 54 countries over the last two years â€“ is prompting renewed warnings from the UN about the threat these digital blackouts pose to freedom of expression, access to information and human rights.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Dangerous nostalgiaâ€™ is a threat to multilateralism, UN deputy chief tells Danish MPs
entry.summary: United Nations Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed urged countries to protect the UN Charter in a powerful speech to the Danish Parliament on Thursday, urging countries to â€œstand up for a rules-based orderâ€ â€“ or pay the price.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Renewed clashes risk derailing fragile transition
entry.summary: A tense standoff between the Syrian Government and Kurdish-led forces in the countryâ€™s northeast risks igniting wider instability just as Syria struggles to emerge from years of conflict and authoritarian rule, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Winter attacks in Ukraine, looming food aid cuts in Nigeria, drought in Kenya
entry.summary: Russian forces launched a fresh wave of strikes across Ukraine this week which have left hundreds of thousands of families without electricity and heating amid freezing temperatures.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: For every $1 spent protecting nature, $30 goes to destroying it
entry.summary: The world spends billions to protect nature, but trillions are being invested in business activities that harm the environment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: War crimes probe pledges to continue work for justice and accountability
entry.summary: As President Trump launched the international Board of Peace plan for Gaza on Thursday, top independent rights experts tasked by the UN Human Rights Council with investigating grave abuses linked to the Hamas-Israel war pledged to continue their work seeking justice and accountability for all.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: These 7 retreats are perfect for night-sky watching
entry.summary:
Stargazing might sound like something to do while camping in a dark forest or trekking a secluded mountaintop. But with the recent rise in astrotourism, driven in part by large-scale events like theÂ 2026 solar eclipse, more people are seeking new experiences under the starsâ€”without sacrificing the comforts of a cozy cabin, lodge, or hotel.Â
Case in point, 62 percent of 27,000 travelers surveyed in aÂ 2025 travel predictions report by Booking.comÂ said they plan to travel for stargazing, making it a popular travel trend in 2026, too. In response, dark-sky state parks and other low-light pollution escapes are now adding chic star-friendly stays.Â
(These are the best stargazing sites in North America.)
Adam Krason, an architect and principal ofÂ ZMM Architects & Engineers, recenâ€¦

entry.title: The fitness habit that may matter most for longevity
entry.summary:
A recent study by Harvard T.H. Chan's School of Public Health finds that incorporating different types of exercise into your workout routine could significantly boost your mortality rate. Should you go all in on walkingâ€”or switch up your workouts during the week? A new study compares the longevity benefits of various types of popular exercises.
Is your workout routine feeling stale? Shaking up your exercise routine can helpâ€”and it might just increase your chance of living longer too.
While itâ€™s well documented that exercise lowers your associated mortality risk, few studies so far have investigated whether or not diversifying your exercise matters. But according to a new Harvard University study, in the long term, exercise variety makes a significant difference in longevity, râ€¦

entry.title: Which wild plants are safe to eat? This is what an herbalist wishes you knew.
entry.summary: Renowned herbalist Mimi Prunella Hernandez answers wide-ranging questions on natural remedies, growing herbs at home, and what really makes a plant medicinal in our latest subscriber-exclusive Ask an Expert Anything Q&A. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2601-ask-an-expert/builds/main/html/_graphic.html

entry.title: The worldâ€™s oldest rock art discovered in Indonesia
entry.summary:
Shinatria Adhityatama examines cave art in one of the caves of Sulawesi, Indonesia. Recently, archaeologists found the earliest-known rock art in the world in the Liang Metanduno cave on the Indonesian island of Muna. The 67,800-year-old hand stencil looks like a clawâ€”and provides new clues about early human cognition and the migration to Australia.
On Muna, a tropical island off southeastern Sulawesi, Indonesia, lies a cave decorated with prehistoric paintings. Locals call it Liang Metanduno. They visit the archaic art gallery to marvel at depictions of flying human figures, boats filled with passengers, and mounted warriors drawn with red, brown, and sometimes black pigment.
In 2015, Adhi Agus Oktaviana, an archaeologist at Indonesiaâ€™s National Agency for Research and Innovaâ€¦

entry.title: Get hands-on in the kitchen in these gourmet hotels
entry.summary:
Sri Lankaâ€™s tea industry was born by accident, after a fungus wiped out the islandâ€™s coffee crops. Discover 12 hands-on food experiences where local traditions, expert makers and unforgettable flavours bring each destination to life.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Food is often the compass that guides our travels, the promise of something simmering, spiced or sweet pulling us across borders as surely as any landmark. A good meal delivers joy, of course, but it also tells a story. Seek out a placeâ€™s culinary traditions and youâ€™re not just eating, youâ€™re uncovering history, ritual and identity, one dish at a time. From learning the art of hand-pressed tortillas in the Guatemalan highlands to watching golden layers of baklava emerge from a centâ€¦

entry.title: Can the basilica that inspired Notre Dame return to glory?
entry.summary: The BasilicaÂ of Saint-Denis, just north of Paris, attracts few visitors, considering its profound historical import. Not only is it the final resting place for dozens of French kings and queensâ€”itâ€™s often called the royal necropolis of Franceâ€”Saint-Denis is also the birthplace of Gothic architecture. The pointed arches, the lofty ribbed ceiling vaults, the light pouring in through tall stained glass windowsâ€”all of those innovations first came together here in the 12th century. Soon they were imitated at churches across France and Europe, most famously at Notre Dame, six miles to the south. They still can be admired to this day at Saint-Denis. But the basilicaâ€™s most prominent Gothic feature cannot: the bell tower at its north front corner, topped by a stone spire that once soared to nearlyâ€¦

entry.title: Why is country music booming in Brazil?
The greatest library in the world was built by this ruthless king
entry.summary:
Ashurbanipal, the most powerful king of the Neo-Assyrian Empire in the mid-seventh century B.C., was known for his ruthless military prowess, his incredible lion-hunting skillsâ€”and for being a librarian.
â€œPalace of Ashurbanipal, King of the Universe, King of Assyriaâ€ reads an inscription denoting his ownership on one of over 30,000 clay tablets and fragments from the magnificent library he maintained at his capital, Nineveh, today in northern Iraq.
The 19th-century discovery of the library by British archaeologists was a game changer for Assyrian studies. Previously, documented sources on Ashurbanipal consisted of one reference in the Bible and often fanciful accounts of his life in later classical texts.
With the discovery of the tabletsâ€”on which scribes had used reeds to iâ€¦

entry.title: What scientists learned from a mysterious surge of Canadian turtle deaths
entry.summary:
Each spring, biologist GrÃ©gory BultÃ© catches turtles that have spent the winter hibernating under the frozen surface of Ontarioâ€™s Opinicon Lake. For over 20 years, heâ€™s marked and returned turtles to the water as they wake from their slumber so he can keep an accurate head count.
In April 2022, he spotted something he hadnâ€™t seen before: a dead turtle in the water.
Its shell was smashed, and its limbs were missing. BultÃ©, an associate professor at Carleton University, went home for his wetsuit and returned to swim in the area. He found another dead turtle, then another. Soon, he was filling bins with them.
"At first I was afraid," he says. "You just keep picking them up, saying 'when is this going to end?'"
This was the first and, so far, the only time BultÃ© had eveâ€¦

entry.title: This Swiss region honors its heritage with a witch's ski race
entry.summary:
Skiers dressed in elaborate witch costumes participate in the Belalp Hexe festival in Switzerland's scenic Valais region. The festival, which includes races and witch-themed activities, is a mischievous take on a haunting local legend. The annual Alpine event pays homage to a local legend about a sorceress and her hapless husband.
The legend goes like this: in the 15th century, a witch lived in the Valais region of Switzerland, and was unhappily married to a local farmer named Sepp vom Hegdorn. She was reclusive and mean, with a loud piercing laugh, and rumors swirled among the villagers that she possessed supernatural powers. At night, they said, she transformed into a raven to visit her lover in a nearby town. By contrast, vom Hegdorn was sweet and unassuming, and ignored the vilâ€¦

entry.title: Literary travel ideas for every kind of book lover
entry.summary:
Vacations centered around books are in high demand. Vacations built around books and authors are on the rise thanks to BookTok. From author retreats to festivals to tours, here are a few ways to connect with your love of the written word.
One of the most enjoyable aspects of travel is the time to read a good book, so it's not that surprising that vacations built entirely around books and authors are on the rise. Thanks to forces such as BookTok, celebrity book clubs, and niche tour operators, literary travel has become a dominant trend.
â€œBook vacations offer a built-in point of connection,â€ says Gabi Valladares, founder of the in-person and digital book club The Literary League who has led reading retreats of her own and for the Catskill Mountains resort Scribnerâ€™s Lodge. Not â€¦

entry.title: Our attention span is shrinking. Here is how you can get it back.
entry.summary:
Research shows that average attention spans are shortening, largely due to frequent interruptionsâ€”but scientists say focus can be rebuilt. Cognitive scientists explain whatâ€™s driving the precipitous decline in our ability to focusâ€”and offer evidence-based strategies to restore it.
Think about the last time you paused what you were doing to check something elseâ€”an email, a message, a notification. How far into your original task were you before you switched? For most people, the answer is less than a minute.
Over the past two decades, researchers have found that the average time people stay focused on a single task has dropped from about 2.5 minutes to roughly 40 seconds.
That erosion of sustained attention is linked to higher stress, more errors, and reduced productivity.â€¦

entry.title: This Canadian â€˜desertâ€™ is British Columbiaâ€™s secret winter oasis
entry.summary:
Osoyoos, a small town in the Okanagan Valley of British Columbia, has emerged as a popular winter vacation destination because of its relatively mild winters and sunny days. Osoyoos draws snowbirds from across the country for winter wine, farm-to-table dining, and outdoor adventure.
At the southern edge of British Columbiaâ€™s Okanagan Valley, about a five-hour drive east ofÂ Vancouver, Osoyoos holds a distinction found nowhere else in the country; the town lies within Canadaâ€™s arid, almost 'desert-like' ecosystem. Framed by sagebrush hills, vineyards, and orchards, this pocket of the South Okanagan is among the nationâ€™s warmest and driest regions. While summers are famously sun-soaked, itâ€™s winter that has become Osoyoosâ€™ most compelling season.
When much of Canada is locked in â€¦

entry.title: At the edge of war: the Central African Republic's uneasy border with Sudan
entry.summary: The land flattens on the approach to Birao, a cut-off town ringed by savannah in the far north of the Central African Republic, where roads dissolve into dust and motorcycles vastly outnumber cars. Less than two hoursâ€™ drive from the Sudanese border, this is the edge of a fractured country still piecing itself back together, while absorbing the shockwaves of a neighbouring conflict.

entry.title: World enters era of â€˜global water bankruptcyâ€™
entry.summary: The world has moved beyond a water crisis and into a state of global water bankruptcy, says a new flagship report released on Tuesday by UN researchers.

entry.title: Prison breaks and renewed clashes raise alarm in northeast Syria
entry.summary: The United Nations continues to monitor developments in northeast Syria following clashes between government troops and the Kurdish-led SDF militia during which scores of detained ISIL militants reportedly escaped from prison.

entry.title: Cold and dark: UN rights chief condemns Russian strikes on Ukraineâ€™s power grid
entry.summary: Russian attacks on Ukraineâ€™s energy infrastructure have cut heat, electricity and water to hundreds of thousands of civilians in freezing winter conditions, prompting the UN human rights chief to denounce the strikes as â€œcruelâ€ and a clear violation of international law.

entry.title: Human trafficking depends on corruption at every step
entry.summary: In 2011, a trafficker in Chile was convicted for recruiting economically vulnerable Peruvian citizens and arranging for them to be brought into the country â€“ destined to become victims of sexual exploitation.

entry.title: Mozambique floods heighten disease, malnutrition risks â€“ UN agencies
entry.summary: Catastrophic flooding across Mozambique is devastating lives and livelihoods, sharply increasing the risk of disease outbreaks and malnutrition, while also forcing dangerous wildlife â€“ including crocodiles â€“ into flooded urban areas, the UN warned on Tuesday.

entry.title: UNRWA headquarters bulldozed in East Jerusalem
entry.summary: The reported demolition underway early Tuesday of the headquarters of UN agency UNRWA by Israeli forces in occupied East Jerusalem - apparently â€œunder the watch of lawmakers and a member of the Governmentâ€ - has prompted swift condemnation from the global body.

entry.title: Why Serre Chevalier is great for a family ski trip
entry.summary:
The snowy slopes of Serre Chevalier are perfect for families at all ski levels. Straddling multiple valleys in the heart of Franceâ€™s Hautes-Alpes, Serre Chevalier is a playground for both kids and parents â€” offering miles of mountain pistes, top tuition and a buzzy new family-friendly resort.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
When Eric Peythieu was growing up in Chantemerle in the French Alps, he and his friends had a simple way of deciding whether you were a proper skier. â€œWe came to the top of this slope,â€ the 58-year-old ski instructor remembers, as he gathers his class above the final stretch of the black-rated Luc Alphand piste. â€œThen we skied straight down. No turning. No stopping. Back then, the piste wasnâ€™t smooth like it is now â€” it waâ€¦

entry.title: An insiderâ€™s guide to Oklahoma City
entry.summary:
Intersected by Americaâ€™s legendary Route 66, Oklahoma City exemplifies the bold spirit of the modern American West. In this welcoming city, travellers can visit a working cattle stockyard, shop for authentic Western wear, tour world-class museums or kayak down a wild river under the vast prairie sky. Visitors will find inventive cocktails, stellar Mexican cuisine and exciting tasting menus featuring local produce all across the city.
Start exploring with a self-guided tour of the domed Oklahoma State Capitol. The grand building is known for its impressive collection of art, including a striking bucking bronco sculpture outside, as well as paintings of Indigenous life by the late American artist and politician Enoch Kelly Haney. Nearby, the First Americans Museum, which opened in 2021,â€¦

entry.title: What are 'football pilgrimages' and why are they on the rise?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Before the first whistle blows, you feel it â€” the drums, the tremors, the electricity rising from a crowd that lives and breathes the game. This is football in South America, and itâ€™s exactly what hooked sports writer Christopher Hylland, sending him on marathon ground-hopping adventures across the continent. With â€˜football pilgrimagesâ€™ booming among fans hungry for authenticity, he lays out what makes these journeys irresistible â€” and why, sometimes, a match is worth crossing an ocean for.
Among many fans in the UK and Europe in particular, thereâ€™s a rejection of the commercialised state of â€˜modern footballâ€™, and I think thatâ€™s why ground-hopping trips or â€˜football pilgrimagesâ€™ abroad have become so popular receâ€¦

entry.title: Cow uses tools to scratch self in scientific first
entry.summary:
Veronika, a Swiss brown cow living in Austria. Veronika the cow has learned to scratch herself with deck brushes and other tools. Scientists took note.
Veronika, a cow living in an idyllic mountain village in the Austrian countryside, has spent years perfecting the art of scratching herself with sticks, rakes, and deck brushes. Now that scientists have discovered her, she has the distinction of the first cow known to use tools.Â
She picks up objects with her tongue, grips them tight with her mouth, and directs their ends to where she wants them most. When sheâ€™s wielding a deck brush, she will use the bristled end to scratch her thick-skinned back, but switches to the smooth handle when scratching her soft, sensitive belly.Â
In a new study, published in the journal Currentâ€¦

entry.title: How Gregor Mendelâ€™s pea plant experiments created modern genetics
entry.summary:
Gregor Mendel, Austrian botanist and founder of genetics, poses for a photograph circa 1860. Between 1856-1863, Mendel bred almost 30,000 pea plants in his monastery garden which demonstrated that hereditary characteristics were inherited from the parent plants. Mendelâ€™s monastery garden experiments went largely unnoticed during his life, but their implications would ripple through science decades later.
Hidden away in a rural monastery in current-day Brno, Czech Republic, Gregor Johann Mendel planted the seeds of modern genetics.Â
Known today as the â€œfather of modern genetics,â€ the Austrian peasantâ€™s chosen career as anÂ Augustinian monkÂ had gotten off to a disappointing start: He had been deemed unfit to work as a parish priest due to â€œunconquerable timidity,â€ as his mentor, â€¦

entry.title: Rising hunger and displacement pose growing economic risk, UN tells Davos
entry.summary: As global leaders gather at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week, UN agencies are warning that rising hunger and displacement are not only humanitarian emergencies but growing threats to global economic stability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Alarmingâ€™ increase in use of death penalty last year, despite global trend towards abolition
entry.summary: Despite a downward trend in the use of the death penalty globally, 2025 saw an â€˜alarmingâ€™ increase in the number of executions in a small number of retentionist countries, the UN human rights office (OHCHR) warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Atrocities â€˜repeated town by townâ€™, ICC prosecutor tells UN Security Council
entry.summary: Atrocities in Sudanâ€™s Darfur region are spreading from town to town in an organized campaign of violence that includes mass executions, rape and ethnic targeting, amounting to war crimes and crimes against humanity, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court told the UN Security Council on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Food insecurity in Lebanon, Libya migrants freed, UNHCR tackles multiple emergencies â€“ despite cuts
entry.summary: Since 2026, nearly 17 percent of Lebanonâ€™s population has been living in a state of major food insecurity â€“ a situation that is likely to worsen in the coming year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: Children are dying and itâ€™s going to get worse, warns aid veteran
entry.summary: In Yemen, renewed political instability and economic woes linked to the war threaten to complicate the already difficult task of helping vulnerable people suffering from deepening hunger, illness and displacement, the UNâ€™s top aid official there said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The art of museum dioramas
entry.summary: From fluffing feathers to washing skins, a museum taxidermist shows the hidden art behind creating an â€˜illusion of lifeâ€™ - by Aeon Video Watch on Aeon

entry.title: Our unfinished republics
entry.summary: Economic republicanism shows us how to achieve authentic freedom: citizens require economic as well as political power - by Sean Irving Read on Aeon

entry.title: Watch Artemis II roll out aboard the heaviest vehicle on Earth
entry.summary:
For the first time since the end of the Apollo program in 1972, humans are returning to the moon. And while they wonâ€™t land on the surface, NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch, and Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen plan to slingshot around the moon on the Artemis II mission this spring. All eyes are on February 6, 2025, which is when the launch window opens.
In preparation for the big day, NASA personnel moved the Artemis II rocket to its launch pad this weekendâ€”and it was no easy feat. It involved a complex choreography with some of the most massive machines on Earth.
Artemis II consists of the Orion crew capsuleâ€”with its launch abort systemâ€”nestled on top of the behemoth SLS rocket. All told, it stands 322 feet tall and weighs roughly 3.5 million pounâ€¦

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Sydney
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The capital of New South Wales is a city of grand harbours and glorious beaches, with a laidback lifestyle to suit its coastal locale. With just 14 hours to explore the city, it's possible to discover the nearby tropical rainforest, enjoy salmon ceviche while watching the surfers beachside and raise a glass in front of the Harbour Bridge â€” here are the best things to see and do.
Watching the sun come up over the Pacific Ocean isnâ€™t just a pastime in Sydney â€” itâ€™s a ritual. Head first thing to Bronte, a laid-back beachside suburb on the cityâ€™s eastern coast for a windswept dip in its ocean-fed rock pool. Bronte Baths isnâ€™t as famous as Bondi Icebergs, a mile north, but its position on the southern edge of the beacâ€¦

entry.title: UN rights chief bears witness to trauma and resilience in Sudan
entry.summary: Nearly three years of war have plunged Sudan â€œinto an abyss of unimaginable dimensionsâ€ and human rights must be at the centre of efforts to end the fighting and build lasting peace, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said on Sunday in Nairobi.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tokyo listening barsâ€”what are they and where to find them
entry.summary:
Talking is generally allowed in listening bars, yet it is often seen to disturb the music experience. The phenomenon of listening bars originated in Japan â€” and in frenetic Tokyo they offer a unique way to switch off, wind down and find inner peace.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the Tokyo pleasure district of Shibuya, amid the nightclubs and the love hotels, an electric sign flickers a pink slogan: â€˜Music from the BYGâ€™. I walk through the door and find myself inside a classic rock â€™nâ€™ roll drinking hole. Twentysomethings sit clustered around wooden tables, leather jackets studded with spikes and hair sculpted into rockabilly pompadours. Half-smoked cigarettes billow plumes of smoke from silver ashtrays. Monochrome renderings of Elvis Prâ€¦

entry.title: Gaza humanitarian crisis â€˜far from being over,â€™ UN aid coordination office warns
entry.summary: Three months into the ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, the UN and partners have delivered tonnes of assistance items and carried out critical repairs, but this is only a temporary â€œBand-Aidâ€ solution, a veteran aid worker has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Secretary-General on UN at 80: Humanity strongest when we stand as one
entry.summary: Powerful forces are lining up to undermine global cooperation, United Nations Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warned at a landmark event in London on Saturday to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the General Assembly, but he urged that â€œhumanity is strongest when we stand as oneâ€.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Will AI kickstart a new age of nuclear power?
entry.summary: The rapidly expanding use of artificial intelligence worldwide is putting electrical grids under huge pressure and many believe that, to meet that need without contributing to the climate crisis, a full-scale expansion of nuclear energy is essential.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Can the cruise industry go carbon-neutral?
entry.summary:
Emissions from cruises in Antarctica have found to be higher than anywhere else in the world. Can the cruise industry hit its carbon-neutral targets? A new generation of ultra-low emission vessels may hold the answer.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In November 2021, the Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA) made an ambitious proposal. Its member lines, which together form 95% of the global cruise fleet, announced a collective pledge to pursue net-zero emissions by 2050. Perhaps recognising the scale of the undertaking, Pierfrancesco Vago, then chairman of CLIA Global, was quick to adopt a tone of cautious optimism. â€œWe know there is more to be done,â€ he said. â€œBut the cruise industry has shown both its commitment and its capability tâ€¦
